III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 2/9/23 Staff 1 slammed Youth E to the floor. On 2/7/23, Staff 2
punched Youth S in the ribs in his room. Neither youth was
injured as a result.
Investigation On 2/10/23 I notified Youth E’s and S’s foster care workers of this
investigation assignment. Neither worker expressed additional
concerns regarding the facility.
Residential Director (RD) said she notified facility supervisors Staff
1 cannot be alone with Youth E and Staff 2 cannot be alone with
Youth S pending the outcome of this investigation.
2

There are no incident reports and no video footage for the alleged
incidents as there are no cameras in the youth bedrooms.
I interviewed Residential Director (RD) who is also the
Complainant, jointly with Government Worker 1. She said Youth
E told her Staff 1 slammed him to his bedroom floor on 2/9/23 and
denied being injured as a result when they spoke.
I interviewed Youth E jointly with Government Worker 1 at school
on 2/13/23. He said on 2/09/23 or 2/10/23 at 5am, Staff 1 told him
to get up, smacked his face, yanked his foot, and pulled his whole
body off the bed onto the floor. His right elbow hit the floor
causing pain. Youth E said no one else witnessed this.
As previously indicated, Youth E denied any injuries when
reporting this to RD. Today, on 2/13/23, he explained he
previously injured the same elbow on his own, but never told the
residential staff about it. Youth E claimed the incident with Staff 1
on 2/9/23 exacerbated a previous elbow injury and that his elbow
still hurts. Government Worker 1 and I observed Youth E’s right
elbow and there were no visible marks. However, asked to flex
and raise his right arm, Youth E complained of pain. I informed
RD that Youth E is experiencing pain in his right elbow and asked
that he be examined by a medical professional as soon as
possible.
Medical documentation from West Park Urgent Care dated
2/14/23 indicated Youth E was examined and x-rayed with no
evidence of joint effusion or abnormality.
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for two years. Staff 1 said Youth E has
difficulty getting out of bed for school on most days. When he
walks through the hall calling for the youths to get up, he said
Youth E usually whines and resists. Staff 1 was unable to recall
exactly how Youth E got out of bed on 2/9/23. “I may have started
taking his covers off. I’m pretty sure I tapped him on the
shoulder.” Staff 1 admitted sometimes “grabbing his arm and
helping him up.” If he still does not get up, “I lecture him (about
the consequence which is three days of early bed) or let a
supervisor deal with him.” Staff 1 denied ever smacking the
youth’s face, pulling his foot, or pulling his body onto the floor.
A review of Staff 1’s employee file showed disciplinary write-ups
for attendance only.
3

I asked RD for more details about the alleged incident between
Youth S and Staff 2. She said Youth S told her Staff 2 punched
him in his ribs in his room on 2/7/23 around 6pm, after Youth S
threw a plastic fork at Staff 2.
I attempted to interview Youth S jointly with Government Worker 1
at school. School personnel requested his presence twice and
both times, he refused to be interviewed. Youth S reportedly told
the Vice Principal he knew what we (Government Worker 1 and I)
were there for and refused to talk with us.
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for three years. On 2/7/23, Staff 2 said
Youth S was disrupting the group and the supervisor asked him to
take the youth upstairs (to his room.) “I told him to sit on his bed
and I sat in the hallway…His dinner was brought upstairs. Youth
S said ‘F’ me and he would kill me. He threw a plastic fork with
one prong on the floor…For thirty minutes, he kicked and punched
the wall, tossed the fork, was cussing and saying, ‘Staff do too
much.’”
Asked why Youth S was angry, Staff 2 responded, “I don’t know.”
Asked about his relationship with Youth S, he said “We get along.
On 2/8/23 after school, he gave me a (plastic) bracelet.”
A review of Staff 2’s employee file showed disciplinary write-ups
for horseplay and using inappropriate language.
On 2/27/23, Youth T told Government Worker 1 that Staff 1
yanked him off his bed by his leg one morning to get him up. I
conducted a follow-up interview of Staff 1 jointly with Government
Worker 1 via telephone on 3/3/23. Again Staff 1 denied yanking
or pulling youth or threatening to physically get them out of bed.
He reiterated, “I pat them on the back and pull their covers off.” If
the youth refuse, Staff 1 said he warns them he will report their
behavior and they could receive consequences such as limited
activities or an early bedtime.
Analysis There is no evidence Staff 1 pulled or slammed Youth E from his
bed onto the floor on 2/9/23 and Youth E did not complain of injury
upon initial report. However, four days later, Youth E complained
to investigators of elbow pain resulting from the alleged incident.
A medical examination and x-rays on 2/14/23 showed no joint
effusion or abnormality.
4

There is no evidence Staff 1 yanked Youth T off his bed by the
leg. There is also no evidence Staff 2 punched Youth S in the ribs
in his room on 2/7/23. There were no witnesses to this alleged
event and no injuries.
CONSULTATION
Staff 1 admitted he sometimes uses interventions such as
removing the youths’ blankets and/or taking a youth’s arm to help
him get up out of bed in the morning for school. I recommend the
facility develop a special behavior plan for Youth E with regard to
getting out of bed that includes acceptable interventions to handle
resistance. Additionally, I recommend the facility identify
acceptable and prohibited interventions when encouraging youth
to get up for school. It is notable that the agency was previously
provided Technical Assistance in Special Investigation
2022C0207001 related, in part, to waking youth up in the morning
and included a reminder to staff to take care when physically
interacting with youth in any manner.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is compliant with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be continued.
